title: 112_s3602
content: The "Food Stamp Restoration Act of 2012" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It establishes a Food Stamp Block Grant Program. The Food Stamp Restoration Act of 2012 establishes a food stamp block grant program for fiscal years 2014 through 2021. Participating states must meet requirements including work, drug testing, citizenship verification, and limitations on benefit uses. The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) grant amount for each participating State is determined based on the number of legal residents with income below 100 percent of the poverty line in the State compared to all participating States. Each State receiving a SNAP grant must submit an annual report to the Secretary by January 1, detailing the program's structure, administration costs, rainy day fund status, and participation statistics. The Comptroller General of the United States conducts an annual audit on the effectiveness of the nutritional assistance block grant program and how each State implements it. A report is submitted to Congress by June 30 detailing the audit results and the State's plans for the food stamp program, including eligibility and fraud prevention measures. The State receiving a grant under this section can use it to provide food stamps to residents as they see fit. The grant funds must remain available to the State for 5 years, after which they will either revert to the Federal Government for deficit reduction or be used to reduce the Federal debt. The curr_chunk states that the Secretary of the Treasury can determine the appropriate manner for the use of grant funds. The Secretary of the Treasury can determine the appropriate use of grant funds. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2014 to 2021 totaling $40 billion to $45.9 billion. Discretionary Spending Limit Adjustment under the Balanced Budget Act amended to increase limits. In paragraphs (5) to (10), figures for appropriations are adjusted to $1,148.6 billion to $1,279.9 billion. Additionally, discretionary spending limits are amended to $550 billion. In subparagraphs (C) to (I)(ii), figures are adjusted as follows: $560.7 billion, $571.6 billion, $583.4 billion, $596.2 billion, $610.1 billion, $623 billion, and $635.9 billion. SEC. 4. REPEALS. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is repealed effective September 30, 2013, including the supplemental nutrition assistance program funded through direct spending. Effective September 30, 2013, amendments are made to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974, including changes to entitlement authority and other direct spending provisions. The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 was amended to update provisions related to the supplemental nutrition assistance program, now referred to as the food stamp block grant program. SEC. 5. BASELINE. The baseline assumes no benefits provided under the supplemental nutrition assistance program after September 30, 2013.
